Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Scalable quantum photonic devices based on vertical quantum dots and photonic crystals

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to address the problem of scalability of semiconductor quantum photonic devices currently limited by the inherently random nucleation process of self-assembled quantum dots. The approach is to design, fabricate, and characterize a novel type of vertical quantum dot, which can be precisely positioned in large quantity by top-down fabrication techniques with respect to photonic crystal resonator modes.
Intellectual Merit: Quantum information science is a fast growing and highly interdisciplinary field with the potential to cause revolutionary advances in science and engineering. Spatial arrangement of several quantum dots with respect to a cavity mode is still an open issue and formation of quantum networks seems quite challenging. The proposed approach offers a pathway to overcome these challenges and demonstrate scalability. If successful, this work will also lead to the demonstration of multi-photon entanglement on a chip and opens up fascinating possibilities to investigate advanced quantum optical effects such as photon blockade in cleaner systems and under very controlled conditions.
Broader Impact: The proposed work is transformative in nature since the anticipated scalable quantum photonic devices enable novel applications in on-chip quantum information processing, quantum communication, quantum lithography, and national security. The educational activities integrate research in nanotechnology in form of a Nanophysics Summer School for undergraduates, as well as high-school and community college teachers. Underrepresented groups will be motivated and encouraged to participate via the Stevens Technical Enrichment Program and the research will be disseminated to K-12 students within the NSF GK-12 program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: In this program on-chip devices have been built that emit photons one by one, i.e. at the level of individual light quanta. These so called single photon sources are required in on-chip quantum information processing applications and for future distributed quantum computing networks. To this end the program explored two semiconductor nanostructures as potential candidates; gallium arsenide based vertical quantum dots and carbon nanotubes. For both material systems it was demonstrated that registered fabrication of the quantum emitters can be achieved into predefined locations on a chip, which is an essential requirement for scalability. Beyond scalability this program addressed open questions of the fundamental light-matter interaction mechanisms in carbon nanotubes with a particular focus on the interplay of light with excitons (excited electron-hole pairs) and phonons (vibrational energy quanta). Several techniques have been developed to manipulate the material properties, and specifically the dielectric environment of individual carbon nanotubes, all with the goal to enhance either the light emission rate, the spectral purity, or the coherence length of the emitted photons. The following lists some key outcomes of this program with respect to efficiency and performance advances of on-chip single photon sources that are based on carbon nanotubes:

A)   Demonstrated a polymer encapsulation technique based on nonpolar polystyrene that is capable of eliminating detrimental quantum blinking and spectral diffusion in carbon nanotubes. Data indicated stable photoemission up to hours of observation time without a single jump of the quantum emitter into the off-state, implying not only stable but also more efficient light extraction in on-chip single photon sources.

B)    Developed a dielectric cavity device that achieved 150-fold enhanced single-photon emission extraction from an individual carbon nanotube.

C)   Discovered a new regime of intrinsic exciton photophysics characterized by a two orders of magnitude prolonged spontaneous emission times, ultra-narrow spectral linewidth, as well as four-fold prolonged exciton coherence times. This was accomplished by advances in the surfactant-free registered growth of ultra-clean and free-standing carbon nanotubes carried out in collaboration with the Wong group and Hone group at Columbia University.

D)   Demonstrated ultra-narrow linewidth with spectrally-resolved phonon sidebands for co-polymer dispersed carbon nanotubes. This hybrid co-polymer-nanotube material, was provided by the Blackburn group at NREL and embedded at Stevens into dielectric cavities. Detailed studies and quantitative models revealed the underlying photophysics and could attribute the enhanced optical properties to a simultaneous localization of heat and charge at the nanoscale, as provided by the helically-wrapped copolymer backbone.

E)    In parallel efforts this program explored novel ways to fabricate plasmonic crystals and demonstrated that 4-beam holographic lithography is highly applicable to the field of plasmonics. The key outcome is a novel all-optical technique allowing to write nanometer sized patterns with 20 nm gap size at wafer scale by optical interference lithography instead of expensive electron beam lithography. Demonstrated plasmonic crystals feature dipole modes, multi-pole modes, and even Fano-resonances with high optical quality factors.
